The Starry Night by Vincent Van Gogh.term: The Starry Night by Vincent Van Gogh
The Starry Night by Vincent Van Gogh.passage: 'The Starry Night', also known as 'Starry Night over the Rhone' in French, is a painting by Dutch post-Impressionist artist Vincent Van Gogh. It is one of his most recognizable works. The painting, which he began in 1889 in Arles and ended in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence in 18810 was first shown publicly by the Dutch post-Impressionist artist Paul Gauguin at the 1904 Exposition Post-Impressioniste in Paris, where it received universal acclaim. The painting, which depicts the town of Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, was sold in 1986 at auction for $504 million, making it the third-highest sold artwork in the history of art, the highest price for any Van Gogh painting, and one of the most expensive of any artwork overall.

The Last Supper by Leonardo da Vinci.term: The Last Supper by Leonardo da Vinci
The Last Supper by Leonardo da Vinci.passage: The Last Supper, painting by Leonardo da Vinci, c. 1498 (right panel). It is one of his most famous works. The painting, which is also known as The Last Supper of Jesus, is an 8.9 x 4.5 ft (2.7 m x 1.3 m) painting on a single panel. Painted at the end of Leonardo's life, it portrays the moment when Jesus declares "This is my body" during the meal, and the apostles drink his wine and eat his bread (Luke 22:19), a depiction which is the basis of all subsequent Christian depictions of the Last Supper. The painting is one of the most iconic images in the world. It was painted during Leonardo's time at the court of the Florentine government, as a commission for an altarpiece to commemorate the Fifth Lateran Council in 1518. Leonardo's painting of the Last Supper was made in oil on a large wooden panel. He painted Jesus as a young man sitting in a high-backed chair with a napkin at his feet and with his feet crossed. He appears to be saying something to the others around him, possibly his farewell words or the words of the other apostles. Behind him is a landscape painted in fresco and finished with light tones of blue and a bright yellow sky. His painting of the Last Supper is generally accepted as the earliest depiction of the Last Supper in Western art.

The Kiss by Gustav Klimt.passage: "The Kiss" is a painting by Gustav Klimt painted in 1908. It depicts two lovers, lying in a comfortable embrace, their faces turned to each other and kissing. The painting is considered a landmark in modernism and a key work in the 'art of feeling'. Klimt's works with its sensuous and sensual characters, decorative and decorative elements have strongly influenced subsequent art. Klimt created at least two versions of The Kiss, one of which he showed to his friend and model (one of his models was later in a nude pose with a crown-like head). Klimt completed two works that included 'A Kiss' in a series of drawings (the other one is a painting of "The Kiss". They are both part of the same "kissing" scene). The painting was completed in May 1908. In November 1908 Gustav Klimt received the Gold Medal at the Society of Painters. The painting is today in the Kunsthistorisches Museum Vienna. -- [This entry was originally posted on the 27th of February, 2006.] This text has been marked for revision in order to improve it. Renaissance.passage:
From Wikipedia:
Renaissance is the Western European period between the 14th and 17th centuries when a renewed emphasis on learning, individualism, and reason became widely expressed in Europe. The period is defined by a renewed and widespread pursuit of knowledge and learning by artists, scientists, scholars, and tradespeople, as opposed to the preceding Dark Ages and Middle Ages. Renaissance artists and writers made use of Latin and classical themes to depict ancient Greek and Roman culture in the style of medieval humanism. Renaissance ideas and inventions influenced the arts, sciences, and humanities throughout the 17th century and beyond, with the influence remaining present in the works of modern scholars, artists, and writers.

Jesus.passage:
“The exact cause of Jesus' death is still a subject of some dispute among scholars, with the general consensus being that Jesus died a crucified death by Roman nails and/or by a nail driven through his left wrist. The precise age of his death is also uncertain, with the consensus being that he died in his mid-30s or late thirties. The Roman Empire was at its wane, and many of its troops and garrisons were being withdrawn to meet the growing threats posed by barbarian tribes in Europe, the most famous of which, the Goths, were under the command of an army at the gates of Rome in AD 537. Thus it is likely that Jesus' death was a natural result of the empire's disintegration and barbarian invasion. The Romans also knew of Jesus' existence in his lifetime, as is proven by the references to him in several ancient Jewish and Roman documents.”[

Katsushiro Okami.passage: Born 27 March 1982 at Shizuoka, Japan, Katsushiro Okami was a Japanese professional jiu-jitsu practitioner who is widely regarded as the most successful competitor in the history of the sport. He trained under Yoshokawa Yoshinori, whom he defeated in several competitions. He was the first person to use the technique of "Katsushiro Okami" jiu-jitsu to win a championship in 2006, when he took gold at the 2006 European Open in Paris, France. Gustav Klimt.passage:
“For more than a century, Gustav Klimt has been a well-known figure of Vienna, Austria, and perhaps the most famous artist of the Post-Impressionist movement. Klimt created a unique style that has become recognizable to viewers today. Although his style has often been referred to as ‘flamboyant’ or ‘over-the-top’ the most important characteristic of Gustav Klimt’s works are their distinct quality and originality. There are approximately 1,800 known paintings of Gustav Klimt’s artwork with most of them being oil paintings. Some of the most recognizable paintings are his works on canvas and his frescoes. Gustav Klimt’s work has been very popular in the United States and the United Kingdom. With many works in collections throughout Europe, many art museums have sought to acquire Klimt’s art. Among his most popular and sought-after works are ‘The Kiss’ and ‘Self-Portrait.’”
I’ve been thinking of Gustav Klimt a lot lately. I know his art is “unique” in terms of style and technique, and I can appreciate it. Yet, his work (and I mean “his” in a different light) never captures me. What do you think? I’ve never really been a Gustav Klimt fan, although his work is always interesting to me.

Paris.passage: The Latin name for the place was originally "Alesia" (or "Alis," from the Celtic word "Alise" which means "to burn"), though it was later Latinized as "Paris" (or "Aparitium"). The city was named after the Gaulish Paris ("Alis" or "Alise") from which it derived its name in Gaul, and which also gave its name to the city in the Middle Ages and Renaissance.

qae_pairs.question: What is the name of the city known as 'Paris' in Celtic times?
qae_pairs.explanation: The name of the city known as Paris in Celtic times is Alesia (or Alis).
